docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a physician who specializes in pain management, I recognize that many patients with chronic pain can benefit from opioids and either do not receive them or receive inadequate doses (''Misunderstood Opioids and Needless Pain''). This often reflects physician ignorance about the proper use of these medications. However, this problem is not limited to opioids alone.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the uncomfortable realities of the war on terrorism is that we Americans have killed many more people in Afghanistan than died in the attack on the World Trade Center. Over the last couple of months I've tried to tabulate the Afghan death toll. My best guess is that we killed 8,000 to 12,000 Taliban fighters, along with about 1,000 Afghan civilians.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed column by Nicholas D Kristof says American invasion of Afghanistan may end up saving one million lives over next decade; says that under Taliban rule, international organizations were retreating from country because of arrests of Christian aid workers, even as hundreds of thousands of children died before age of 5, and thousands of women died during pregnancy or childbirth; says aid is now pouring in and lives are being saved on enormous scale; says if West lives up to its obligations to help Afghanistan and not abandon it as was done decade ago, potential savings in human lives are staggering (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government and the United Nations signed an agreement creating a special court to try people accused of committing atrocities during the West African country's decade-long civil war. The tribunal, to be based in the capital, Freetown, is expected to try around 20 people who will be charged with crimes against humanity, war crimes and other serious violations of international law. Those expected to be indicted include Foday Sankoh, the leader of the Revolutionary United Front, a rebel group that killed and chopped off the limbs of thousands of civilians. The rebels, who have turned in their weapons under a peace plan brokered by the United Nations, say members of government forces also committed atrocities and should be tried.
docs.abstract: Government of Sierra Leone and United Nations sign agreement creating special court to try people accused of committing atrocities during country's decade-long civil war (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bill Keller warns that the Bush administration will be ''standing on the sidelines'' if it continues in its refusal to get caught up in enthusiasm for a permanent international criminal court (''The Monster in the Dock,'' column, Feb. 9). But the plainly political nature of such a court is entirely at variance with the notion of what a court should be: a disinterested administrator of justice.

docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary General Kofi Annan authorized a war crimes tribunal today to be set up in Sierra Leone despite a big shortfall in financial pledges from the member nations of the United Nations. Mr. Annan said a United Nations planning mission would go to Sierra Leone on Monday to start the process of arranging headquarters for the special court, hiring local staff members and beginning investigations.
docs.abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan authorizes war crimes tribunal to be set up in Sierra Leone despite big shortfall in financial pledges from member nations of United Nations; tribunal's task will be to prosecute 20 people accused of being ringleaders of Sierra Leone's decade-long civil war, which pitted government forces and militias against rebels of Revolutionary United Front, who became notorious for hacking off limbs of owmena nd children, and for enlisting thousands of child soldiers intheir cause (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United Nations is pressing ahead with arrangements for a special war crimes court in Sierra Leone that officials say will be leaner and less bureaucratic than the tribunals that were created to prosecute war criminals in the Balkans and Rwanda. The United Nations signed an agreement with Sierra Leone two months ago creating a legal framework for trying a score of defendants accused of atrocities in the West African country's civil war.
docs.abstract: United Nations presses ahead with arrangments for special war crimes court in Sierra Leone that officials say will be leaner and less bureuacratic than tribunals created to prosecute war criminals elsewhere; new court will enlist judges and lawyers in Sierra Leone as well as prominent jurists from outside country; Secretary Gen Kofi Annan will appoint majority of judges; Sierra Leonean government would select other judges and chief prosecutor; score of defendants ae accused of atrocities in country's civil war (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Slobodan Milosevic faced his first victim of the war in Kosovo today in court, he paused for a moment before asking questions. He blew out a little breath. He frowned. He rustled his papers, then put his hand on his chin. The witness, Agim Zeqiri, 49, had his own way of managing a cross-examination by the very man whose troops, he said, had massacred his wife and five children in March 1999. Maybe it was fear, or maybe disrespect, but Mr. Zeqiri kept his back turned.
docs.abstract: Slobodan Milosevic, acting as his own lawyer at his war crimes trial, cross-examines Agim Zeqiri, who says Serb troops massacred his wife and five children in Kosovo in 1999; Zeqiri testifies with his back turned to Milosevic; denies under questioning that Kosovo Liberation Army, armed Albanian guerrilla group, had been in his small village on last day he saw his family; insists that only Yugoslav forces were there, burning down houses and shooting civilians; Milosevic does not ask questions disputing that civilians were killed; rather, he implies that attack was justified by presence of Kosovo guerrillas, which Zeqiri denies over and over again (M)
